title: Brexit news Sky News Adam Boulton Theresa May deal European Union
story: The experienced Sky News journalist, 59, and Editor at Large was filmed swearing on live TV outside Number 10 Downing Street. It comes amid a day of chaos during confusion over whether the Prime Minister would deliver a press conference following a crunch Brexit meeting with her cabinet. Adam Boulton was filmed saying: &ldquoOne minute we're f***ing lining up, and then the next minute...                'May is FINISHED!' Theresa May to face vote of no confidence NEXT WEEKThe host is believed to have been preparing for a live broadcast for Sky News when he was filmed rolling his eyes and swearing on an ITV News live stream.It comes a month after the Sky News host was recorded swearing at colleagues in a leaked on-air outburst.Theresa May is expected to deliver a statement to the media after meeting with her cabinet to rally support for the draft Brexit Withdrawal Agreement.After two years of intense negotiations with the European Union, negotiators have broken the deadlock to finalise a draft Withdrawal Agreement.Adam Boutlon was filmed live on-air swearing amid Brexit chaos on Downing Street (Image: ITVNEWS)But, there was confusion over whether the Prime Minister was to deliver a press conference of a statement following the cabinet meeting.Policing Minister Nick Hurd told the Commons there would be no press statement on the draft deal on Wednesday evening.He said: I am authorised to inform the House there will be no press statement this evening.There was considerable concern in the House about that happening before the prime minister came to Parliament.However, the Policing Minister reportedly misspoke, with officials claiming Mrs May will make a short statement, but not a press conference.The official said: The PM will make a short statement after Cabinet concludes.&ldquoThe PM will make a statement to the Commons tomorrow. There is no press conference tonight.After the conflicting statements were made earlier this evening Labour MP Gareth Thomas&nbsprasied&nbspa point of order in the Commons seeking clarification.He said: I am seeing on social media that despite the minister saying there would be no statement about the Cabinet discussions on Brexit, that there is now due to be a statement by the Prime Minister to the press afterwards, I wonder if there is any way we can clarify the situation?Policing Minister Mr Hurd was passed a mobile phone from a Tory backbencher, before responding. He said: &ldquoWhat I said at the despatch box was what I was authorised to say, I've got no further update.

title: Theresa May Brexit statement in full news EU UK deal European Union
story: The Prime Minister insisted the orce deal she secured earlier this week from the European Union will help deliver the demands of the 2016 referendum. Theresa May has been facing increasing pressure from Brexiteers in her party claiming her proposal would betray the demands of Leave voters. Mrs May also announced she will give a statement in Parliament on Thursday to update MPs about the Cabinet meeting.                Sky News' Adam Boulton SWEARS live on-air amid day of Brexit CHAOSSpeaking to the press outside of Number 10, Theresa May said: &ldquoThe Cabinet has just had a long, detailed, and&nbspimpassioned debate on the draft withdrawal agreement and the outlined political declaration on our future relationship with the European Union.&ldquoThese documents were the result of&nbspthousands of&nbsphours of hard negotiations by UK officials and many, many meetings which I and ministers held with our EU counterparts.&ldquoI firmly believe that the draft withdrawal agreement was the best that could be negotiated.&ldquoAnd it was for the Cabinet to decide whether to move on in the talks. The choices before us were difficult, particularly in relation to the Northern Ireland backstop.Mrs May continued: &ldquoBut the collective decision of Cabinet was that the Government should&nbspagree on&nbspthe draft withdrawal agreement and the outline political declaration.&ldquoThis is a decisive step which enables us to move on and finalise the deal in the days ahead. These decisions were not taken lightly but I believe it is a decision in the national interest.&ldquoWhen you strip away the&nbspdetail,&nbspthe choice before us is clear.&ldquoThis deal, which delivers on the result of the referendum, which brings back control of our money, laws and borders, end free movement, protects jobs, security and our union &ndash or leave with no deal. Or no Brexit at all.Theresa May claimed she had the backing of the cabinet with her Brexit deal (Image: SKYNEWS)She concluded: &ldquoI know there will be difficult days ahead. This is a decision which will come under intense scrutiny and that is&nbspentirely&nbspas it should be&nbspand&nbspentirely understandable.&ldquoBut the choice was this deal which enables us to take back control and to build a brighter future for our country or go back to square one, with more ision, more uncertainty and a failure to deliver on the referendum.Mrs May also announced plans to give a statement in front of MPs on Thursday to defend the Cabinet&rsquos decision to back her tentative Brexit deal.The Prime Minister added: &ldquoIt&rsquos my role as Prime Minister to explain the decisions the Government has taken and I stand ready to do that beginning tomorrow with a statement in Parliament.&ldquoIf I could end by just saying this. I believe what I owe to this country is to take decisions in the national interest and I firmly believe, with my head and my heart, this is a decision which is in the best interests of our entire United Kingdom.Despite her positive report outside Number 10, many sources have claimed Esther McVey was the most vocal and it was reported that she was &ldquoshouted down by the Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill after demanding Cabinet voted on the deal.Sources say she is on the brink of resigning.

title: Brexit news Michel Barnier UK EU withdrawal agreement Theresa May latest
story: The EU&rsquos chief negotiator stood triumphantly as he announced his team has reached agreement on a draft withdrawal treaty and a political declaration on the outline for the framework of a future relationship with Mrs May. A future trade deal &ldquowon&rsquot need much time, according to the negotiator who stressed the UK and EU&rsquos tradition as close partners make the agreement easier to reach. But his words will continue to infuriate Brexiteers in the UK who have been hypercritical of the Prime Minister for potentially allowing the UK to slip into a permanent customs union with the EU.                Brexit news: Verhofstadt warns May that Brussels will decide on dealMr Barnier told reporters in Brussels that both sides are drawing up plans for a &ldquofree trade area based on regulatory and customs cooperation for the basis of their future relationship.He said: We&rsquore drawing the basis for an ambitious partnership which we want which is a free trade area based on regulatory and customs cooperation in depth and with a Level Playing Field.&ldquoOur objective is to abolish customs duties and quotas for all goods based on what we&rsquore proposing in the withdrawal agreement, a single customs territory.Of course, as the EU Council gave me a mandate, that will be the condition of the new agreement on fisheries will apply.Brexit news: Michel Barnier outlines plan for UK's future EU partnership (Image: )There will be no tariffs on goods and indeed it is legitimate for that proposal to be flanked by a level playing field that&rsquos a voluntary deliberate agreement between two parties who respect each other.&ldquoThis agreement offers a basis for future negotiations and that is in our common interest.&nbspHe added: We&rsquore preparing and we&rsquoll be ready to start that negotiation the very day after the UK withdraws from the EU on the 30 March 2019.Negotiators from the UK and EU eventually agreed on a UK-wide customs backstop as the final insurance policy of avoiding a hard Irish border.Last Friday, Mr Barnier&rsquos Deputy Sabine Weyand said the &ldquobasis for the future arrangement should be the UK-wide customs backstop.A joint EU-UK report published alongside the withdrawal agreement states the future partnership will be build on the single customs territory provided for in the withdrawal agreement.                'She hasn't got the numbers' Parliamentary arithmatic will DOOM May                What did Theresa May say in Brexit speech TODAY?The withdrawal agreement states: Having regard to the Union and to the United Kingdom's common objective of a close future relationship, which will establish ambitious customs arrangements that build on the single customs territory provided for in this Protocol, in full respect of their respective legal orders.Mr Barnier stressed that it is not in the EU&rsquos interest to allow the backstop, which would lock Britain in a customs union with the bloc, to be used at all but insisted it should remain in the withdrawal deal.He said the backstop is &ldquonot meant to be used and the UK and EU's objective is to reach a permanent solution before the end of the 21-month transition period.In July 2020, both sides will hold a joint review of the position before making one of three choices: deciding a trade deal supersedes the need for the backstop, a limited extension to the transition period or trigger the backstop.Mr Barnier said: If we are not ready by July 2020 we could jointly consider extending the transition to provide for more time.&nbspOnly if at the end of the transition extended or not we are still not there with the future agreement would the backstop solution kick in.&nbspThis backstop solution has evolved considerably from the original EU proposal.Brexiteers will once again be left infuriated by the lack of an independent review clause, which will allow the UK to unilaterally quit the backstop.The backstop will only able to be ended &ldquojointly by both sides and will apply until that moment is reached.The withdrawal agreement reads: &ldquoIf at any time after the end of the transition period the Union or the United Kingdom considers that this protocol is, in whole or in part, no longer necessary to achieve the objectives set out in Article1(3) and should cease to apply, in whole or in part, it may notify the other party, setting out its reasons.&ldquoWithin six months of such a notification, the joint committee shall meet at ministerial level to consider the notification, having regard to all of the objectives specific in Article 1. The joint committeemen may seek an opinion from institutions created by the 1998 Agreement.&ldquoIf, following the consideration referred to above, and acting in full respect of Article 5 of the withdrawal agreement, the Union and the United Kingdom decide jointly within the joint committee that the protocol, in the whole or in part, is no longer necessary to achieve its objectives, the protocol shall cease to apply, in whole or in part.Both sides have agreed to uphold the withdrawal agreement in good faith, which means either the UK and EU can make suitable challenges to one another if they feel their side of the bargain is not being upheld.

title: Brexit news UK deal EU fishing Theresa May European Union fishermen
story: British fishermen have warned they could be betrayed by the Prime Minister's&nbspBrexit draft agreement with the European Union. Fishing chiefs have raised concerns with the text within the &lsquopolitical declaration on the future relationship&rsquo and warned they could be forced into a deal similar to that of the Common Fisheries Policy. Fishermen in the UK already feel they have been deeply let down by the Government after the announcement of the implementation period effectively kept the industry under the control of the EU&rsquos controversial Common Fisheries Policy until 2020. But, the text in the 'political declaration on the future relationship' suggests that while Britain will be an &ldquoindependent coastal state, future cooperation on the development of measures &ldquofor the conservation, rational management and regulation of fisheries will be done in a &ldquonon-discriminatory manner.Fishing for Leave told Express they were, while still studying the &ldquoexact meaning of the opaque language in the Brexit text, worried it looked &ldquodeeply suspicious.A Fishing for Leave spokesman said: &ldquoA lot of the wording used is disconcertingly similar to the regulations and treaties founding the CFP, in particular, the&nbspnon-discrimination&nbspprinciple, which in effect means equal access to a common resource.&ldquoWe may officially &lsquoleave&rsquo but, in effect, this new deal and new legal agreement may be different wording, but will create the same effect as a Common Fisheries Policy.&ldquoIt may not be called that, but, if it walks like a Common Fisheries Policy, and quacks like a Common Fisheries Policy, it is a Common Fisheries Policy.Fishing for Leave spokesmanThe political declaration on the future relationship sets out the &ldquoframework for the future relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, as agreed at negotiators' level on 14 November 2018.Focusing on &ldquofishing opportunities, the document reads: &ldquoCooperation bilaterally and internationally to ensure fishing at sustainable levels, promote resource conservation, and foster a clean, healthy and productive marine environment, noting that the United Kingdom will be an independent coastal state.&ldquoWhile preserving regulatory autonomy, cooperation on the development of measures for the conservation, rational management and regulation of fisheries, in a non-discriminatory manner. Close working with other coastal states and in international fora, including to manage shared stocks.It adds: &ldquoWithin the context of the overall economic partnership,&nbspestablishment&nbspof a new fisheries agreement on, inter alia, access to waters and quota shares, to be in place in time to be used for determining fishing opportunities for the first year after the transition period.Brexit news: British fishermen were very suspicious with the agreed Brexit text (Image: )Bertie Armstrong, chief executive of the Scottish Fishermen's Federation urged the Government for clarity on the proposed new fisheries agreement.Mr Armstrong said: &ldquoThe industry&rsquos priority has always been taking back control of decision-making over who catches what, where and when in our waters, so that we can end once and for all the grossly unfair situation where 60 percent of our stocks are taken, gratis, by boats from other EU nations.&ldquoThat would mean the UK becoming a fully independent coastal state with its own seat at all the relevant international fisheries negotiations from December 2020 on and regaining its proud status as one of the world&rsquos major fishing nations. Negotiations over trade terms for seafood products would follow on from this. Any linkage between access and trade contravenes all international norms and practice and is simply unacceptable in principle.&ldquoTherefore we have asked the Prime Minister for assurances that the establishment of a new fisheries agreement as laid out in the Brexit arrangements does not imply that EU vessels will be guaranteed continued access to our waters in return for favourable trade terms.On Wednesday the cabinet&nbspwere&nbsplocked in discussions for around five hours before the Prime Minister emerged and stood on the steps of 10 Downing Street to announce she had the backing of her team on the future relationship.Mrs May said: &ldquoThe Cabinet has just had a long, detailed, and impassioned debate on the draft withdrawal agreement and the outlined political declaration on our future relationship with the European Union.&ldquoThese documents were the result of thousands of hours of hard negotiations by UK officials and many, many meetings which I and ministers held with our EU counterparts.&ldquoI firmly believe that the draft withdrawal agreement was the best that could be negotiated. And it was for the Cabinet to decide whether to move on in the talks. The choices before us were difficult, particularly in relation to the Northern Ireland backstop.Mrs May continued: &ldquoBut the collective decision of Cabinet was that the Government should agree on the draft withdrawal agreement and the outline political declaration.&ldquoThis is a decisive step which enables us to move on and finalise the deal in the days ahead. These decisions were not taken lightly but I believe it is a decision in the national interest. When you strip away the detail, the choice before us is clear.&ldquoThis deal, which delivers on the result of the referendum, which brings back control of our money, laws and borders, end free movement, protects jobs, security and our union &ndash or leave with no deal. Or no Brexit at all.

title: brit trying to claim universal credit told he must take his first day off at his new job to go to a job hunting meeting
story: Geraint Jones, , who lives in Reading, has been trying to get help on the new benefits system after he lost his job earlier this year.He’s managed to find a new one and is due to start in a couple of weeks, but has bizarrely been told he must attend a mandatory job-hunting meeting at his local job centre anyway, or he won’t be entitled to a penny.The IT sales worker, who has also served in the RAF, told The Sun Online: “They said I still need to come in and meet a job coach.“I’m away for a few days visiting my elderly mum so they told me to take my first day off at my new job - to help me get a job!“It’s just ridiculous.”Geraint, known to pals as Taff, fears he will go into debt as a result of being unable to get help on Universal Credit during the days he’s out of work.He was trying to claim the Jobseekers’ Allowance and Housing Benefit parts of Universal Credit - just to help him for  days when he was between jobs.He waited until his final pay cheque had come through from his old job - another trap that many other claimants can fall into - to make sure his benefit wouldn’t be affected.And after spending weeks hunting, he was delighted to find a new job.But Taff’s pay will likely outweigh any benefits he could get anyway, meaning he won’t be able to get any help for the time he’s been out of work.“I’m quite worried about the next few weeks,” he said.“They say the system encourages people to work as quickly as possible but it’s in my financial interest to not start work until next month so I’ll be entitled to benefits.“It seems designed to do as much as they can not to pay out.“I’m just an ordinary people in a bit of a bad situation and just want some help to get me through.“I served in the forces, I want my little bit back that I’m entitled to.”Now Taff thinks hell not be able to claim the £ to help with his housing and bills, that Universal Credit staff thought he could be entitled to.Taffs just one of many who have had problems on the new system, which many say has pushed them into debt.But officials said it was too late now to half the whole process - even though millions of Brits have been affected by the problems.The Chancellor revealed a new funding boost which will help Brits on the new scheme, but it wont kick in for millions until at least next April.The DWP say any new claimant needs to attend a job centre interview to discuss what they need to do to find work - and whether they are entitled to cash help when they are in it.A spokesperson said: When applying for Universal Credit, people will be asked to meet with their Work Coach to agree a Claimant Commitment.If they already have a job this commitment might include ways to progress in work and increase their pay, rather than looking for work.”

title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. title: eu army emmanuel macron angela merkel latest
story: Merkel declared there should be an integrated European Union military, recalling the lessons of the First World War and the isions that led to the conflict.Speaking to MEPs today about the future of Europe, Merkel said the continent should take its fate fully into its own hands.Echoing comments made by French leader Emmanuel Macron last week, she said: We should work on a vision of one day establishing a real, true European army.Merkel added that such an army would not undermine the US-led military alliance NATO but could be complementary to it. It should include common development of arms industry, she said as well as an EU-wide arms export policy and crucially a European intervention force.It came a day after a senior minister from the French Government called for the EU to become a powerful new “empire” to rival the US and China in an interview which will infuriate Donald Trump.Merkels remarks today in the EU parliament drew loud applause in the legislature but also boos from euro-sceptic members.One of them was chief Brexiteer Nigel Farage, who said: Its a European Union that we are told is now to become an empire - a militarised European Union.A European Union that has launched a new Cold against the United States of America.One hundreds years on from the Armistice we should genuinely be worried.The idea that this new militarised union is somehow a recipe for peace I suggest you sit back and think a little bit more carefully.Maybe you should all re-read history because the European project was set up to stop German domination and what you have seen today is a naked take-over bid.Yesterday French finance minister Bruno Le Maire said Europe must be strong enough to defend itself in the future - words the US president called insulting.Le Maire controversial calls for a new superstate came as he backed Macron’s and Merkels plan for a “real European army”.Le Maire suggested Brussels should go one even further and establish itself as an “empire”.Its about Europe having to become a kind of Empire, as China is. And how the US is, the French finance minister told the German newspaper Handelsblatt.After being quizzed by the newspaper on his comments, he added: “Do not get me wrong, Im talking about a peaceful empire thats a constitutional state.I use the term to raise awareness that the world of tomorrow will be about power.Power will make a dference: technological power, economic, financial, monetary, cultural power will be crucial.Trump has blasted Macrons idea for the European Union to build an army to protect itself from the US as insulting.The US President tweeted: President Macron of France has just suggested that Europe build its own military in order to protect itself from the US, China and Russia.Very insulting, but perhaps Europe should first pay its fair share of NATO, which the US subsidises greatly!It comes three days after the French President said the US is as big a threat to the EU as Russia and China and called for a “true European army” to defend the bloc.In an extraordinary attack on the US president, Macron lumped Washington together with Moscow and Beijing as Europe’s biggest foes.The arch euro federalist insisted only a fully fledged EU defence force can protect the continent against the trio’s aggression.He said: “We have to protect ourselves with respect to China, Russia and even the United States of America.“We will not protect the Europeans unless we decide to have a true European army.”The French president lashed Mr Trump for deciding to pull the US out of a nuclear treaty with Russia that was signed during the Cold War.He raged: “When I see President Trump announcing that he’s quitting a major disarmament treaty which was formed after the s euro-missile crisis that hit Europe, who is the main victim  Europe and its security.”Mr Macron made the comments in a radio interview from the town of Verdun - the site of a major WW battle - as he tours the Western Front ahead of Remembrance Day.They were welcomed by the EU Commission, which said it has already put the wheels in motion for the eventual creation of a euro army.A spokesman beamed: “If there is a Commission that has put forward the need for a meaningful defence identity for the EU, it’s this Commission.“President Macron has been consistently putting forward this narrative for a stronger Europe that empowers and protects.“This is totally totally compatible with our work and all contributions from our EU leaders, and especially from President Macron, are very much welcome.”But the remarks were savaged by former British Army commanders, who said the revelations showed why the UK must pull out of the EU’s defence plans.Major General Julian Thompson, who led British forces in the Falklands, told The Sun: “The EU Commission now openly admits it has created the preamble to an EU army.The UK is in that preamble and risks being kept in it.“Ministers must withdraw or risk losing forever whole chunks of the UK’s democratic control over defence.”Colonel Richard Kemp, a commander of UK troops in Afghanistan, added: “This is precisely what eurosceptics have been warning about.“It is time for ministers now to take notice and rein in what they have agreed since the referendum.They have been led astray in the most crucial area of sovereignty.”And Tory MEP Geoffrey Van Orden, a former British Army Brigadier, raged: “Instead of th century dreams of French-led European grandeur, President Macron should be helping build Western solidarity.“That means helping and not obstructing a strong partnership with Britain and strengthening the NATO alliance.”

title: brits wont need a visa to travel to europe even if we get a no deal brexit eu confirms
story: UK citizens will be able to visit the EU for up to three months at a time without having to get new documents - eventhere is a No Deal Brexit.The European Commission today unveiled plans for a new visa regime after Britain leaves the EU in March next year.Eurocrats said: The European Commission has today proposed to grant UK citizens visa-free travel to the EU after the United Kingdoms withdrawal from the European Union.It would mean that UK citizens would not need a visa when travelling to the Schengen area for short stays of up to  days in any -day period.Brits who want to work in Europe, or visit for more than three months, may still need to get a visa.And holidaymakers wont be able to use the fast lane at passport control - meaning there could be much longer queues for British people at European airports.The commission also warned that under a No Deal scenario, British driving licences and pet passports could be useless on the continent.The new regime will come into force in four monthsBritain ends up crashing out of the EU without a withdrawal deal.Butwe do get a deal, it will only apply after the end of the transition period which will conclude in December .The EU said that the offer of visa-free travel will be withdrawnthe UK refuses to let Europeans come in without a visa.Theresa May has already promised not to impose visas on holidaymakers from Europe.But it was previously feared the EU would charge Brits £ or more for a permit to enter after Brexit.Todays announcement applies to all the countries of the EU except Ireland, plus Norway, Switzerland, Iceland and Liechtenstein.Freedom of movement between the UK and Ireland is already guaranteed under a separate treaty dating back to .A Government spokesman said: A UK government spokesperson said: We welcome the proposal by the European Commission which reflects the future relationship that the UK wants with the rest of the EU.We have been clear in our proposals that we want to ensure reciprocal measures on visa-free travel for tourists and short term business visitors with the EU.”Anti-Brexit campaigners claimed the new rules will hurt British citizens who spent large parts of the year abroad.Lib Dem MP Tom Brake said: This will come as a real shock to those who spend their winter months in Spain or Portugal and will now see additional costs and potential queues providing extra baggage.

title: passenger cathay pacific nut allergy peanuts onboard
story: Sophie Marriott, , said she was now terried about tomorrow’s Cathay Pacic flight to Sydney, with no guarantee she would not be surrounded by other passengers eating the nuts.Speaking to the Sun Online, Sophie broke down as she said: “I’m terried.“I can’t explain how scary it is to go through anaphylactic shock.“The thought of being in the air, in a confined space – it’s terrying.”Sophie said she had initially booked the flights - costing £,with her partner months ago - flagging her nut allergy immediately.The young woman, of Saint Albans, Herts, said she was then given a form for her doctor to sign that would guarantee crew would not serve peanuts to the passengers in her cabin.But she said her doctor took issue with one of the paragraphs in the statement, which reads: “The passenger’s peanut and or other nut allergy condition do not pose any serious risks to his her health given the conditions inflight as stated in attached.”She explained: “It says that there would be no risk of me having an allergic reaction.“But I’m still at risk, there’s always a risk.”The young woman said she had even started wheezing while on a train and sitting next to someone eating peanuts - showing just how deadly the food could be for her.Sophie then provided a statement from her doctor confirming her peanut and nut allergy – but was told last week by the airline it wasn’t enough.The marketing worker said: “I provided this for proof – why they need proof I just don’t know.“Even though they know I have a peanut allergy, they are still going to serve peanuts as a cocktail snack.“I don’t know what  I can do.”Anaphylactic shock is a severe and potentially fatal reaction to a trigger such as an allergy.It normally comes on suddenly, and gets worse very quickly.Symptoms include:A sufferer may also display symptoms of allergies, such as an itchy raised rash , feeling or being sick, swelling or stomach pain.Cases of anaphylaxis can be fatal - like in the case of Megan Lee, who an inquest heard likely died of an anaphylactic shock after eating a meal from the mice-infected Royal Spice takeaway in Oswaldtwistle, Lancashire.It comes after -year-old Natasha Ednan-Laperouse died from an allergic reaction while flying with British Airways.The young woman had eaten a baguette from Pret A Manger that had not sufficiently labelled there were sesame seeds inside the sandwich.Sophie said Cathay Pacic yesterday gave her a second medical clearance form about .pm – and told her they needed it ed by the end of the day.Sophie then tried to get a doctor to look over the form but was told the timeline would be impossible.The young woman said she was now desperately trying to get the form signed today – and still didn’t knowshe would fly tomorrow.She said: “The anxiety it is causing – I just don’t know.“I was in tears all day yesterday, I’ve never been put in this position before.“It’s just terrying for me to be sat with everyone eating peanuts.”Cathay Pacic told her to delay her flight, but she said the trip was for a family wedding.She said: “I know it sounds silly – I paid a huge amount of money for this flight and the holiday.“It’s a hell of a lot to throw away because they won’t do this small thing.“At the moment, I literally don’t know what to think.”Cathay Pacic said: “Our team has been trying our best to assist her.”The Sun Online has contacted them for further comment.

title: abu bakr al baghdadi search syria hajin
story: The Sun Online was alongside the battle-hardened warriors as they targeted the warlords henchmen and family in their stronghold of Hajin, east Syria - near where al-Baghdadi is thought to be hiding out.The operation comes just weeks after the so-called Invisible Sheikh ordered the execution of  of his followers for disloyalty from his secret bolthole, which is said to be close to the Iraqi border.“In other battles, the jihadists had other places to run to, but in Hajin they have nowhere to go,” said Commander Havel Ronnie Walat of the Syrian Democratic Forces, which has been fighting ISIS since .“ here it is only the true believers left and they will fight to the death,” he chillingly added.The father of two - who has fought ISIS in Raqqa and Manbij - believes that those Islamic extremists currently left in Hajin includes, mostnot all of ISIS top leadership.In addition to al-Baghdadis relatives many of those still in the area are thought to be the most dedicated of the foreign fighters.“About two months ago we captured this British doctor. He was trying to get to escape to Turkey,” recalls Havel Ronnie.But here is signicant numbers of other foreigners here too - not just British – but many of the top leadership, who are Saudi, Chechen or Iraqi.”ISISs so-called caliphate has been left virtually decimated since they lost their de-facto capital, Raqqa, in Syria last year.However, according to the Havel Ronnie in and around Hajin the bloodthirsty group still control around  square kilometers of villages spotted along the Euphrates river and dislodging them will be extremely dficult.“ISIS have had over five years to prepare, and they have built tunnels and placed IED everywhere… they also know the terrain very well,” he states.“It is very slow work [and] we are having to take it, house by house, metre by metre.”The American-backed coalition recently suffered a major setback last month after the extremists launched a series of counter attacks using the cover of sandstorms.“The sandstorm lasted for almost three days and we could only see meters in front of us,” a female commander explains of that attack.Luckily they suffered no losses at that base, but it was almost over run by the jihadists.Some of those involved in the assault were also foreign fighters.“We captured a Saudi and Afghani…and my [female] comrade shot a blonde European man in the head,” she states pointing near to the ISIS vehicle, where it happened.“He was about to enter our base and explode his suicide vest.”The SDF have recently redeployed some of their elite ‘counter terrorism units to Hajin to bolster their troops in the area.“We will begin the offensive against Hajin soon...but I don’t think this battle will be done quickly” the chief commander explains.“This is not a war that can be won quickly,” he added.Eventhe jihadists do lose Hajin this commander does not believe it will be the end of the terror group.“I am certain that they will be defeated here, but, that will not be the end of ISIS... and what may come after maybe worse, he adds.According to him this is a generational battle which cannot be defeated just by retaking territory.“At least now we and you know where ISIS is but after they are gone, they could attack from anywhere, even in Europe,” he says.In August Baghdadi urged his followers to unleash suicide bombs in the West, just days after he was reported to be brain dead.In the recorded message the worlds most wanted man urged fanatics to follow the striking lions behind recent lone wolf attacks in Europe and Canada.

title: you had one job images photos
story: Even something as simple as labelling a tin of butter correctly has been made a hash of and the people responsible for these hilarious snaps certainly wont be getting a promotion anytime soon.Sometimes the solutions to our everyday problems are so simple that we fail to see it when the answer is staring us right in the face.But even then, some problems can be too hard to deal with for some people.This hall of shame includes everything from grammar mistakes to other-worldly concepts.The outrageous gallery will have you chuckling at some of the funny ways people have mucked up a very simple job.

title: obese children given electric bikes conwy county
story: Conwy Council in North Wales says it wants to help kids with weight management dficulties engage in sport.A pilot scheme involving  local youngsters last year showed overweight children struggled to ride up hills using normal bicycles.And leisure chiefs say the motorised bikes - which use batteries to ease pedalling - will help fat children move around dficult terrain.A report found that a third of all schoolchildren in the borough are overweight.The council was asked to match £, in private funding to pay for five so-called e-bikes after a pilot scheme with a local school.If successful, the cash will be provided by EU funding.The council report said: Having run a pilot scheme on a smaller scale within a local school using traditional bicycles, the evidence was clear that e-bikes can help those with weight management dficulties to engage in sport.Using the bike as a tool to experience the outdoors without the e-bike would not have the ability to ride up hills thus making it more accessible and enjoyable.Other benefits include less time on video games and social media s.Long term goals include making the transition on to traditional cycling and long lasting health benefits including a lower body mass index.But locals say the scheme is another example of council jobsworths wasting taxpayers cash.Bin collections in the area are down to just once a month — while councillors signed off on £million rent commitment on its new headquarters.And despite reduced services, council taxes rose by  per cent this year.Local resident Mair Dempster-Jones, said of the bike plan: Tax payers paying for this nonsense again. Get them walking, that is free.Caroline Dawson added: These kids need to be getting a sweat on, and not given the luxury of power assist over dficult terrain. Theyre eight, not . Sad times.In September Conwy Council became the first local authority in the country to slash bin collections to once every four weeks.Council bosses say it will save £, a year in landfill costs and help meet recycling targets.The Sun Online have contacted Conwy Council for comment.

title: alana burns pregnant mum council flat bathgate west lothian
story: Alana Burns, , is due to give birth to twins in March and lives with children Alisha, two, Steven, four, Cayden, seven, Leigh, , and Caitlin, .Her older children Stewart, , and Bryan, , also live in the flat, which is above a pub in West Lothian.The home has four bedrooms but due to a leak in one room, the family are all crammed into just three bedrooms.They were living in a private let until the landlord decided to sell the property so they spent time in hotels before West Lothian Council found them the flat in September.Single mum Alana said: My relationship with some of my children is at breaking point. We cant keep living like this.The council has been out to the leak and said theyd get in touch with me, I have heard nothing.This has been going on for weeks and it needs sorting out.It is not safe for anyone to be sleeping in that room so were now down to eight people sharing three bedrooms which is ridiculous.I just want to get out of this hell. Id rather live anywhere , as long as it is not in here. It has been really tough.Im feeling down every night and sometimes you just feel like giving up. But I just have to keep going for the sake of the kids.The mum-to-be claims the run-down flat has a string of issues - including no TV, uneven flooring, damaged ceilings and noisy neighbours.She is having to pay out £ a day on electricity because she believes a third party is using her supply and says cant let her children out to play.Alana said: I need a proper house where I can bring up my children. The whole situation is unbelievable.My kids cant go out to play here.The road in front is busy and there is a car park at the back of the property so it isnt safe.All the kids are stuck inside all night crammed in without any TV.West Lothian Council confirmed previous repairs have already been carried out by the landlord and said they were only notied of the leak two days ago.A spokesman added: It can be challenging to find suitable accommodation for large families who present themselves as homeless, given the limited stock of larger homes available.In this case, the council arranged for temporary accommodation from a private landlord to try and meet their housing needs until a permanent home could be found.We would encourage Ms Burns to engage with the offers of support already made, to allow us to help find a solution for her familys housing needs.This includes widening her choice of areas to maximise her opportunities for permanent housing.

title: brexit deal theresa may leadership vote
story: The partys backbench chief Graham Brady will have to call a vote of confidence backbenchers request one.Senior Brexiteers from the European Research Group warned tonight that the threshold could be passed as soon as tomorrow.They insisted there is no co-ordinated plot to unseat the PM - but claimed MPs are so angry that  letters could end up going in anyway.Jacob Rees-Mogg said: The ERG is not trying to force the pace on this but there is the risk of an accident, a lot of people feel very let down and without any organisation might be writing letters.Conor Burns, a close ally of Boris Johnson, told LBC: There’s a lot of febrile talk. What I can tell you is there’s no orchestrated attempt to put letters in.But sensing the levels of frustration and annoyance colleagues are feeling it would not surprise meorganically letters are going in.The ERG has responded with fury to early reports of Mrs Mays Brexit deal.They claim it will leave the UK tied to the EU permanently thanks to the controversial Irish backstop meant to keep the border open.If Sir Graham, chair of the  Committee, receives  letters asking for a confidence vote, he must hold one within days.Mrs May will be kicked out of powershe fails to win the backing of  of the Tories  MPs.Butshe survives, the party cant hold another vote of confidence for at least a year.Some Brexiteers admit that the PM would probably win a vote - but forecast she would be so badly damaged she would have to ditch her current Brexit plans.

title: what is the draft brexit agreement theresa may
story: Heres what we know about the deal and what it could mean for the country.The full details have not yet been made public but Theresa May promised to present the deal to Parliament tomorrow morning in a formal Commons statement.The prime minister insisted that blocking her deal would mean going back to square one, with more ision and more uncertainty.May told the House of Commons earlier today: I am confident that this takes us signicantly closer to delivering what the British people voted for in the referendum.We will take back control of our borders, our laws and our money, leave the Common Fisheries Policy and the Common Agricultural Policy while protecting jobs, security and the integrity of our United Kingdom.She insisted the controversial Irish backstop will not keep Britain tied to the customs union for ever, saying: We dont want to be in a position where the European Union would find it comfortable to keep the UK in the backstop permanently.It also guarantees there will be no hard border between the UK and the Republic of Ireland.The PM faces a mighty showdown with her own backbenchers and the DUP - starting with a crunch meeting with chief unionist Arlene Foster due to take place tonight.Tory Brexiteers have even threatened to bring Mrs May down for good by forcing a vote of confidence in her leadership.Even half of the Cabinet spoke out against the deal before reluctantly agreeing to sign off on it in a bid to avoid the Government collapsing altogether.In a letter to Conservative MPs, European Research Group chairman Jacob Rees-Mogg said they should not support the deal.The proposals released today do not match the expectations set out in Theresa Mays Lancaster House speech, he said.The proposed agreement will see the UK hand over £ billion to the EU for little or nothing in , Mr Rees-Mogg said.The deal is unacceptable to unionists, will lock us into an EU customs union and EU laws and is profoundly undemocratic.For these reasons I can not support the proposed agreement in Parliament and would hope that Conservative MPs would do likewise, he said.The PM warned in her statement tonight that Britain faces a choice between her deal, a No Deal outcome or no Brexit at all, saying: I firmly believe that the draft withdrawal agreement was the best that could be negotiated, and it was for the Cabinet to decide whether to move on in the talks.The choices before us were dficult, particularly in relation to the Northern Ireland backstop.But the collective decision of Cabinet was that the Government should agree the draft withdrawal agreement and the outline political declaration.This is a decisive step which enables us to move on and finalise the deal in the days ahead.These decisions were not taken lightly but I believe it is a decision that is firmly in the national interest.Hinting at the trouble shes likely to face from rebellious MPs, Mrs May added: I know there will be dficult days ahead. This is a decision that will come under intense scrutiny and that is entirely as it should be and entirely understandable.She concluded: I believe that what I owe to this country is to take decisions in the national interest.I firmly believe with my head and my heart this is a decision which is in the best interests of our entire United Kingdom.

title: mechanic girlfriend ring greggs bake
story: Mechanic Tony Brown, , got down on one knee in Newcastle city centre between Greggs and department store Fenwick.And when Rebecca, , said yes, they celebrated with a pie. She said: “It must be the most Geordie proposal ever.“The Festive Bake was totally typical of him — but I was expecting more than a Greggs after.”Tony added: “It has everything, Fenwicks, Greggs — unless Alan Shearer was there or something it couldn’t have got more Geordie.”And he said his decision to celebrate with the best-selling bake — chicken, bacon, stuffing and sage and cranberry sauce wrapped in puff pastry — was a spur of the moment thing.Tony said: “I was hyper and I was starving, and when I turned around there it was — Greggs.”He also offered advice to anyone  thinking of proposing to their partner. title: prince charles 70th birthday party
story: The Prince of Wales and we Camilla joined  readers also reaching that age this year to celebrate at our tea party for them.Four were born on the same day as the heir to the throne, November , .As he and the Duchess of Cornwall, , walked into Spencer House in London, our readers gathered on the steps of the mansion near The Mall and sang Happy Birthday.Later the Prince told them he was partly to blame for the unique celebrations.Charles revealed that on a foreign tour this year, he confided to our Arthur that it would be fun to enjoy reaching the milestone with people who were born on the same day.Prince Charles added: “So he went away without my knowing and this is the result.”Arthur, , who has spent more than  years photographing the Prince, launched a competition to find  readers who make a real dference in their communities.One of the four, Yuriko Davis, was born in Japan on November  — but due to the time dference, it was still the th here.The hospice volunteer, who now lives in Bristol, said: “I wished him happy birthday and he asked methere were many swear words in Japanese. I replied ‘Not as many as French and English’ and he laughed.” David Barker, of Croyde, Devon, was actually born  minutes into November  but just three-and-a-half hours after Charles. He said: “It was my own fault for being late!”The other two are Tony Culley, of Newton Abbott, Devon, and Malcolm Selley, from Barry. Tony said of celebrating with the prince: “It’s the best birthday present I could ever wish for.”And Charles told our lucky winners: “It is an enormous pleasure to see all of you here because I know from Arthur some of the remarkable things all of you have managed to do in your wonderful way, unsung very often, and unseen.“I admire so much the things that you do in so many special ways.“Arthur, when I first saw him, used to be crawling about in the undergrowth but it’s amazing how le changes!“He’s a very good photographer and a jolly good bloke and a very special person.”On behalf of The Sun’s millions of readers, East London transport manager’s son Arthur presented Charles with a huge birthday cake.He also gave him a framed cartoon by Sun cartoonist Brighty, which showed the Prince’s footman bursting in clutching a cake with so many candles he was followed by a fireman. And Charles told our readers: “Thank-you for coming and thank-you for making it an even more special day for me.”In a video played in the plush Great Room at Spencer House, Sally Rickinson, from Scarborough, told how she planned to give the prince a kiss. And moments later, as he met all the guests in turn, he stepped forward and kissed her on both cheeks.Delighted radio presenter Sally said: “It made my day. I think it was because of my remark in the video.”Eileen Thomson revealed she met Charles at a Status Quo concert in Birmingham in  and that he had brought along ear plugs.As they met again, Eileen, from Northampton, askedhe remembered it. He replied: “Yes I do! There were , people singing ‘Charlie Charlie!’ It was quite extraordinary.”And the Prince told Jayne Miller, of Huntingdon, Cambs, that he had been given a boxset of TV comedy classic Last of the Summer Wine as a present.He said: “My grandmother introduced me to it. It’s fantastic. Comedy is not as funny as it used to be.” Jayne laughed and told him: “Too PC now Sir!”Malcolm Reid, who volunteers with cancer charity Maggie’s, of which the Duchess is president, said: “I always knew Charles and Camilla were nice people but it was very special to be able to find out first hand.”John Davies was nominated by we Ella for work he does volunteering as a handyman at the RAC Saddle Club Equestrian Centre in Bovington, Dorset. He said: “My mother had a picture of the Queen on her coronation day on the wall. I never thought I would be lucky enough to spend the day with her son on his birthday. And I was so pleased to meet The Sun’s Arthur Edwards.”Anne Cox, of Glasgow, was invited for her work for the Royal Naval Association and for volunteering at a local daycare centre.She said: “I lost a close friend to cancer just before my th this year, so I didn’t really enjoy my birthday.“I’m going to treat today like my birthday, and celebrate properly today.”Rita Kutt, from Leeds, developed a range of clothing for disabled kids. She said: “He told me he was proud of all of us in the room who had been born the same year as him and done such wonderful things for our communities.”Kathy Cooke, of Blackpool, knits garments for thousands of needy people worldwide. She said of the event: “This has really made my th year so special — and that will be true for everybody here today.”It was a real joy to take him down Memory Lane, but most importantly he loved meeting our readers — amazing people who were all born in the same year as him.When he first mentioned having a party to me I thought it was a good idea.But I didn’t realise it would turn into such a huge success, not just for me or for the Prince and the Duchess, but especially for our readers.We all had an exciting day that we are sure to remember for the rest of our lives.The Prince revealed he has no intention of taking it easy now he has turned .He said: “I was asked outside whether I was going to slow down, I’m not sure I’ve got much alternative but to speed up.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu army terrible mistake
story: But there’s something rather wonderful about Donald Trump’s ability to speak the truth, with no frills attached.And not care who he p***es off. It’s quite unusual in a politician.But then I suppose Trumpo isn’t your usual politician.The US President was at it again in France.The idiotic French President Macron has dug up that idea about a European army, run by those genius minds at the EU.Those of us not keen on the EU always worried about this ridiculous notion — but we were told by pro-EU politicians that it would never happen. Another lie.Macron said Europe should have its own armed forces to guard against interference from Russia, China and — the USA.What a rude and stupid statement to make in the run up to Armistice Day.When French people would do well to remember that it was us — and the Yanks — that saved their benighted country.Sometimes I wonderit was worth it.Trump was right on the case, with one of his famous tweets.He des­cribed Macron’s comments as insulting.And he added thatit wasn’t for the Americans, the French would be speaking German by now. Quite right.And he’s right, too, that the EU nations do not pull their weight when it comes to funding the real alliance against our real enemies, Nato.They all like to snipe from the sidelines at the USA.And resent the Americans for their power, influence and success.And for bailing them out of the last war.But then they expect the yanks to spend vast amounts of money protecting them all.Germany, one of the richest countries in the world, spends only . per cent of its GDP on forces for Nato. That is as pathetic as it is typical.The French themselves spend only . per cent.We’re second only to the Americans in our spending — but even then I would argue that it’s not enough.Our Armed Forces have been cut to the bone over the past two decades.Would we be able to retake the Falkland Islands now,Argentina invaded  I doubt it.The truth is that Nato is the one alliance of which we should be glad to be a member.It is an alliance of largely civilised, largely democratic countries which has held fast against tyrants, despots and warmongers for  years.Most notably, of course, the Cold War, in which the Soviet Union was defeated without a shot being fired.But now Trump is getting a bit tired of Nato because the US always has to spend, spend, spend.And with the Europeans thinking again of having an EU army there are many who think the days of Nato are numbered.That would be a terrible mistake.An EU army to replace Nato It would be bureau­cratic, incompetent and short-funded.And it would surrender before you could say “Macron”.THE Lord Mayor of Sheffield is a ludicrous dingbat called Magid Magid who has been coughed up from somewhere deep in the bowels of the Green Party.Shortly before Remembrance Day he posted a publicity shot of himself online wearing a white poppy and a T-shirt saying “never again!”A good moment, then, to ask the vital question: Have you ever met someone wearing a white poppy who wasn’t a complete and utter moron We wear red poppies to commemorate the terrible loss of le in battle.People wear white poppies to commemorate themselves and their fatuous sensibilities.It’s called showing off.WAGES have risen at the fastest rate for almost a decade.They went up by nearly three per cent in the three months to September, compared to a year earlier – and about time, too. This has been the real problem with our economy.But it looks like we’re on the right track.UH-OH – the Beast from the East is said to be on its way back.You remember late last winter. We were snowed in for a week. Nobody could come to visit.The missus couldn’t get to the shops to buy anything.It was just about perfect. All you need is a few bottles of Jack Daniel’s and some soup. Make sure you’re prepared.LUCKY, lucky earthquake victims.Here’s Paris Hilton in Mexico, visiting survivors of the  earthquake.And giving them bottles of Paris Hilton perfume and cushions with “Paris Hilton” stamped across them.Just exactly what they needed.Paris said: “I love the people, I think they are all beautul, they have great hearts, they are beautul inside and out, they are very genuine and incredible.”Just like you, Paris, just like you. A WOMAN who met the Liberal Democrat peer Lord Lester says she was offered an interesting proposition.Have sex with me, the -year-old goat suggested, and I’ll make you a baroness.Can’t say fairer than that, can you The most I’ve ever offered is a bag of Pickled Onion Monster Munch.Lester has been suspended from the House of Lords as a result.Thing is, it’s always the liberals who get up to this kind of stuff.Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and now Lester.Ladies, I’m telling you,a liberal bloke approaches you in a bar telling you how pro-feminist he is, activate your alarm, call the Old Bill and get the hell out, sharpish.THIS is Sophie Michelle. She makes £k a year by whispering to people over the internet.Usually stuff like: “Hello sweetheart.”She says it stimulates the listener’s “autonomous sensory meridian response”.Which is perhaps the longest phrase for “penis” I have ever heard.MONICA LEWIN­SKY was the young intern who had an affair with President Clinton, back in the s.Come on – you remember. According to reports a cigar was involved.And Monica had a revealing stain on the front of her dress.She’s been talking about the whole episode again.And she says she thought the stuff on her dress was “spinach dip”.Really  If it looked like spinach dip I think Bill should have got himself off to a doctor, pronto.Are you sure it wasn’t cock-a-leekie ASIA BIBI is the Pakistani Christian woman who was sentenced to death for alleged “blasphemy” against the Prophet Muhammad.She then had her sentence commuted and some Pakistani Muslims are going bonkers, as usual.Demanding she have her head cut off. Threatening to kill anyone who supports her.We should give the poor woman asylum in our country, away from the Islamist savages in Pakistan.But the Government fears “reprisal” attacks by the extremists.That’s a gutless response and devoid of ­principle.Give Asia Bibi a home here. We’ll deal with the savagesthey try ­anything on.We’re getting used to it, after all.I’M trying to work out which of the Remoaners I dislike more. Gary Lineker or Tony Blair.I suppose Gary didn’t illegally invade a sovereign country.But then Blair never sported a stupid goatee beard or spent half of his le selling crisps.Although I daresay he would have donethere’d been enough dosh in it.Lineker, like many other remoaners, was demanding a second vote on Brexit. A People’s Vote.Yep, we’ll do that.Just as soon as we can replay football matches because I don’t like the original score.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: energy drink vending machine ban
story: Professor Russell Viner also wants a minimum price put on the high-caffeine, high-sugar cans such as Red Bull.He is also calling for a law barring their sale to under-s, tougher restrictions on celebrity endorsements and lessons on their potential dangers taught in school.The President of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health also suggests putting health warnings on packaging.He spoke in response to a Government consultation on restricting the sale of energy drinks in a bid to combat childhood obesity. More than two thirds of youngsters aged ten to  drink them.Many say they are attracted by low prices and attractive adverts.But doctors, dentists and teachers warn they make kids fat, rot their teeth and leave them restless and disruptive in school.Prof Viner said: “Many children say they drank energy drinks because they wake them up, give them energy and they are cheap. In fact, energy drinks have the opposite effect with their ingredients making them lethargic, agitated and anxious.”He said lessons on the effects on the body of high-energy drinks should be made part of the school curriculum from primary age.He said it would help children to make informed decisions “on issues that can have a huge impact on the rest of their le”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: picture boy hiding leaves
story: But the eagle-eyed UPS driver managed to spot a small boy hiding in the middle of them all near the side of the road in Elkhart,  miles north of Indianapolis.Jordan Weaver, who had been with the company for  months, had just delivered a parcel across the road to a woman who turned out to be the boy’s mum.He told WSBT-TV: “I couldn’t believe it at first -- my heart completely stopped.“Luckily, I parked across the street from the stop, so I didn’t see the child until after I made the delivery.“I immediately grabbed my phone and went and asked the motherI could take a picture.”They recreated the moment with the boy’s head just visible in a bid to spread the word about distracted driving as well as pedestrian safety.“At every location all over the world, we do -minute PCM meetings before drivers go out on the road,” UPS director of corporate media Glenn Zaccara told Yahoo! Lestyle, referring to the company’s pre-work communication meetings.“Part of it is stretching and literally getting themselves ready to go out. But an important part of the PCM is some type of safety message.”Weaver shared his story with his colleagues and sent the photo to someone on a local UPS safety committee program, who then posted it to Facebook.“He could have died,” said Dayana Botello, who saw the photo on the social media website. “I said ‘Oh my goodness, I have to be even more careful in paying attention to our kids.’”Zaccara said the UPS spends almost half a billion dollars on safety and driver training, which Weaver had just completed.Weaver said: “You really have to keep your eyes open.“No matter what street you’re on, no matter where you’re at, just have to keep your eyes open. You have to pay attention to everything around you constantly.”

title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
